me.tatarka.ipromise

Class Promise<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.tatarka.ipromise.Promise<T>

  • public class Promise<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    A promise is a way to return a result the will be fulfilled sometime in the future. This fixes the inversion of control that callback-style functions creates and restores the composeability of return values. In addition to creating a standard interface for all asynchronous functions, Promises can also more-robustly handle error and cancellation situations. You cannot construct a Promise directly, instead you must get one from a Deferred. That is, unless the result is already available.
    See Also:
    Deferred

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Promise.AlreadyDeliveredException
      The Exception thrown if a result has already been delivered and a second result is attempted to be delivered.
      static class  Promise.NotFinishedException
      The Exception thrown if the result is not yet available.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Promise

        public Promise()
        Constructs a new promise. This is used internally by Deferred.

      • Promise

        public Promise(T result)
        Constructs a promise with a result already in it. This is useful for when you can return the value immediately.
        Parameters:
        result - the result

    • Method Detail

      • cancel

        public void cancel()
        Cancels the Promise, notifying all listeners and propagating the cancellation to all Promises that share the CancelToken.

      • isFinished

        public boolean isFinished()
        Returns if the promise has finished and is holding a result.
        Returns:
        true if finished, false otherwise

      • isCanceled

        public boolean isCanceled()
        Returns if the promise has been canceled.
        Returns:
        true if canceld, false otherwise

      • tryGet

        public T tryGet()
         throws Promise.NotFinishedException
        Returns the result if the promise has finished. Use isFinished() to ensure the result has been isFinished.
        Returns:
        the result if the promise has finished
        Throws:
        Promise.NotFinishedException - if the promise has not isFinished the result yet.

      • listen

        public Promise<T> listen(Listener<T> listener)
        Listens to a Promise, getting a result when the Promise completes. If the Promise has already completed, the listener is immediately called. This way you can't "miss" the result.
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to call when the promise completes
        Returns:
        the promise for chaining

      • then

        public <T2> Promise<T2> then(Map<T,T2> map)
        Constructs a new promise that returns when the original promise returns but passes the result through the given Map function.
        Type Parameters:
        T2 - the result type of the new Promise
        Parameters:
        map - the function to chain the result of the original Promise to the new promise
        Returns:
        the new Promise

      • then

        public <T2> Promise<T2> then(Chain<T,Promise<T2>> chain)
        Constructs a new Promise that chains two promises in succession.
        Type Parameters:
        T2 - the type of the second Promise result
        Parameters:
        chain - the Chain that constructs the second Promise
        Returns:
        the new Promise

      • and

        public <T2> Promise<Pair<T,T2>> and(Promise<T2> promise)
        Constructs a new Promise that completes after both the current and given promises complete.
        Type Parameters:
        T2 - the type of the other Promise
        Parameters:
        promise - the other Promise
        Returns:
        the new Promise

      • and

        public static Promise<java.lang.Object[]> and(Promise... promises)
        Constructs a new Promise that completes after all the given promises complete. This method can take any number of promises; however, the returned promise is not strongly typed. Therefore, you only have 2 promises you should use and(Promise) instead.
        Parameters:
        promises - the promises
        Returns:
        the new Promise

      • or

        public Promise<T> or(Promise<T> promise)
        Constructs a new Promise that completes when either the current or given promises completes. The other promise is then canceled.
        Parameters:
        promise - the other Promise
        Returns:
        the new Promise

      • or

        public static <T> Promise<T> or(Promise<T>... promises)
        Constructs a new Promise that completes when one of the given promises completes. The rest are then canceled.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the promises
        Parameters:
        promises - the promises
        Returns:
        the new Promise

      • cast

        public <T2> Promise<T2> cast()
        Forces a cast of a promise to a super-type to get around covariance restrictions. T2 must be a superclass of T. This is safe because you can't directly deliver results to the cast promise.
        Type Parameters:
        T2 - the type of the result to cast to
        Returns:
        a cast of the promise
